title: Chinese Embassy donated Office Supplies to Laos Diplomatic Academy
description: On October 19, 2011, Embassy of China in Laos presented office supplies such as projectors, computers, and printers to the Laos Diplomatic Academy (or 向老外交学院赠送办公用品).
combined_text:

# Title
Chinese Embassy donated Office Supplies to Laos Diplomatic Academy

# Description

evidence: Donation of office supplies to Laos Diplomatic Academy, education sector focus

title: Chinese government provided aid worth 800,000 RMB to the victims of cluster munitions in Laos
description: On August 24th, 2011, Chinese government signed an MOU to provid aid worth 800,000 RMB to the victims of cluster munitions in Laos (or 向老挝政府捐赠集束弹药受害者援助物资). On June 7th, 2012, the ambassador of China to Laos Bujanguo donated the batch of aid to the Lao National Unexploded Cluster Munitions Administration.
combined_text:

On June 7th, 2012, the ambassador of China to Laos Bujanguo donated the batch of aid to the Lao National Unexploded Cluster Munitions Administration.
justification: Project is focused on humanitarian aid and social development, with no direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Aid provided to victims of cluster munitions, humanitarian focus, no energy or infrastructure components

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 24 million grant for provision of 5 CT-scan machines to 5 public hospitals (Linked to Project ID#72488)
description: According to Resolution No. 18 issued by the Government of Lebanon’s Council of Ministers on September 19, 2011, the Chinese Government provided an RMB 26 million grant to the Government of Lebanon for the provision of medical equipment, including RMB 24 million to provide Lebanon's Ministry of Health with 5 CT-Scan machines for 5 public hospitals (captured in Project ID#72487) and RMB 2 million to provide Lebanon's Ministry of Social Affairs with medical equipment and devices (captured in Project ID#72488).
combined_text:
# Sector

# Title

# Description
According to Resolution No. 18 issued by the Government of Lebanon’s Council of Ministers on September 19, 2011, the Chinese Government provided an RMB 26 million grant to the Government of Lebanon for the provision of medical equipment, including RMB 24 million to provide Lebanon's Ministry of Health with 5 CT-Scan machines for 5 public hospitals (captured in Project ID#72487) and RMB 2 million to provide Lebanon's Ministry of Social Affairs with medical equipment and devices (captured in Project ID#72488).
justification: Project focuses on healthcare equipment provision without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Provision of CT-scan machines to public hospitals, healthcare sector focus

title: Chinese Government provides grant for Radio and Television Network Expansion and Equipment Supply Project
description: On May 30, 2011 and June 20, 2011, the Chinese Government and the Government of Lesotho signed an exchange of letters for the Radio and Television Network Expansion and Equipment Supply Project. The monetary value of the grant from the China Ministry of Commerce that supported this project is unknown. The purpose of the project was to help Lesotho National Broadcasting Service (LNBS) install an upgraded audio/video news studio system and non-linear editing system, strengthen the capacity of Lesotho TV technical personnel to maintain the audio/video news studio system and non-linear editing system, and increase TV broadcasting efficiency. This project is part of a larger effort by Lesotho’s Communications Ministry to transition from analog to digital and improve the coverage of Radio Lesotho, Ultimate FM and Lesotho Television.   On April 24, 2012, Anhui Telecom Engineering Co., Ltd. signed an implementation contract and the project officially commenced at the end of 2012. The project was officially completed and handed over to the Government of Lesotho on May 31, 2013. The Chinese Government previously donated more equipment to LNBS (see #31096) and trained LNBS personnel (see #71821). The Chinese government also signed a licensing agreement with LNBS in 2013 (see #71820)
staff_comments: This project is also known as the Lesotho Radio and Television Network Expansion Project and the Lesotho Radio & TV Network Expansion Project with Equipment Supply. The Chinese project title is 中国援莱广电网扩建项目 or 莱广电网扩建项目 or 援莱广电网扩建项目 or 莱索托广播电视网扩建项目 or 援莱广播电视扩建（广播电视设备）项目.
combined_text:
# Sector
COMMUNICATIONS

# Title
Chinese Government provides grant for Radio and Television Network Expansion and Equipment Supply Project

# Description
On May 30, 2011 and June 20, 2011, the Chinese Government and the Government of Lesotho signed an exchange of letters for the Radio and Television Network Expansion and Equipment Supply Project. The monetary value of the grant from the China Ministry of Commerce that supported this project is unknown. The purpose of the project was to help Lesotho National Broadcasting Service (LNBS) install an upgraded audio/video news studio system and non-linear editing system, strengthen the capacity of Lesotho TV technical personnel to maintain the audio/video news studio system and non-linear editing system, and increase TV broadcasting efficiency. This project is part of a larger effort by Lesotho’s Communications Ministry to transition from analog to digital and improve the coverage of Radio Lesotho, Ultimate FM and Lesotho Television.   On April 24, 2012, Anhui Telecom Engineering Co., Ltd. signed an implementation contract and the project officially commenced at the end of 2012. The project was officially completed and handed over to the Government of Lesotho on May 31, 2013. The Chinese Government previously donated more equipment to LNBS (see #31096) and trained LNBS personnel (see #71821). The Chinese government also signed a licensing agreement with LNBS in 2013 (see #71820)
justification: Project focuses on communications infrastructure without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Radio and television network expansion, equipment supply, and digital transition support

title: China grants 5 million M for Solar Street Light Project in Lesotho (Linked to ETCA #1402)
description: In October 2009 at the 4th Ministerial Conference under the Forum on China-Africa Cooperation (FOCAC) Chinese and Basotho government officials signed an unspecified agreement for the solar street light demonstration cooperation project (太阳能街灯示范合作项目) in Lesotho. On 29 November and 7 December 2011, the Chinese Ambassador and Masotho Minister of Finance signed a follow up exchange of letters. An article from Energy China Forum says this project is financed by a 5 million M grant from the Chinese government; which most likely came from ETCA #1402 also signed in December 2011.   On 25 April 2012, the Lesotho Minister of Natural Resources and ZTE representatives signed the implementation contract in which ZTE would provide and install equipment, and send technical assistance teams as well. ZTE pledged to sub-contract some of the works to Masotho firms. The purpose of this project was to install solar-powered street lights in the capital of Maseru and three surrounding districts-- Pitseng, Nazareth, and Mount Moorosi-- covering 4,600 meters of road. Works began in January 2013 and the project was officially handed over on 1 August 2013.
combined_text:
# Sector
ENERGY

# Title
China grants 5 million M for Solar Street Light Project in Lesotho (Linked to ETCA #1402)

# Description
In October 2009 at the 4th Ministerial Conference under the Forum on China-Africa Cooperation (FOCAC) Chinese and Basotho government officials signed an unspecified agreement for the solar street light demonstration cooperation project (太阳能街灯示范合作项目) in Lesotho. On 29 November and 7 December 2011, the Chinese Ambassador and Masotho Minister of Finance signed a follow up exchange of letters. An article from Energy China Forum says this project is financed by a 5 million M grant from the Chinese government; which most likely came from ETCA #1402 also signed in December 2011.   On 25 April 2012, the Lesotho Minister of Natural Resources and ZTE representatives signed the implementation contract in which ZTE would provide and install equipment, and send technical assistance teams as well. ZTE pledged to sub-contract some of the works to Masotho firms. The purpose of this project was to install solar-powered street lights in the capital of Maseru and three surrounding districts-- Pitseng, Nazareth, and Mount Moorosi-- covering 4,600 meters of road. Works began in January 2013 and the project was officially handed over on 1 August 2013.
justification: Primary purpose is installation of solar-powered street lights, directly supporting renewable energy adoption
evidence: Solar-powered street lights, renewable energy focus, covering 4,600 meters of road

title: Chinese Government dispatches 8th Medical Team to Motebang Hospital
description: Since 1997, Hubei Province has been sending medical teams to Lesotho every 2 years. On June 21, 2011, the Chinese Government and the Government of Lesotho signed a protocol agreement, dispatching the 8th Chinese medical team (第八批医疗队) to Lesotho. The team was stationed at Motebang Hospital, which is located on Mandela Road in the town of Hlotse within Leribe District. The 8-member team completed its term of service between September 2011 and September 2013. The team treated 45,000 patients, conducted 1,133 operations, donated equipment, and trained more than 100 local medical personnel.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Chinese Government dispatches 8th Medical Team to Motebang Hospital

# Description
Since 1997, Hubei Province has been sending medical teams to Lesotho every 2 years. On June 21, 2011, the Chinese Government and the Government of Lesotho signed a protocol agreement, dispatching the 8th Chinese medical team (第八批医疗队) to Lesotho. The team was stationed at Motebang Hospital, which is located on Mandela Road in the town of Hlotse within Leribe District. The 8-member team completed its term of service between September 2011 and September 2013. The team treated 45,000 patients, conducted 1,133 operations, donated equipment, and trained more than 100 local medical personnel.
justification: Project is focused on healthcare services and medical training without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Medical team providing healthcare services, training local medical personnel, and donating equipment

title: China Eximbank provides RMB 200 million government concessional loan for Phase 2 of National Telecom Network Project (Linked to Project ID#752)
description: On August 10, 2011, the Chinese Government and the Government of Lesotho signed a concessional loan framework agreement for Phase 2 of the National Telecom Network Project. Then, on December 12, 2011, China Eximbank and the Government of Lesotho signed a government concessional loan (GCL) agreement worth RMB 200 million to support Phase 2 of the National Telecom Network Project. The borrowing terms of the GCL are unknown.   The Government of Lesotho used the proceeds of the loan to on-lend to Econet Telecom Lesotho, a state-owned telecommunications operator in Lesotho. Econet Telecom Lesotho (ETL), in turn, used the loan proceeds to expand, upgrade and modernize Lesotho’s telecommunications infrastructure. Anhui Telecom Engineering Co. was the contractor responsible for Phase 2. Work appears to have began shortly after Anhui Telecom Engineering Co. signed an implementation agreement on April 24, 2012. The project was officially handed over to the Government of Lesotho on May 31, 2013.   ETL did not honor its repayment obligations to the Government of Lesotho under the terms of its on-lending agreement. According to a Report on the Consolidated Financial Statements of the Government of Lesotho for the Three Years 2013/14, 2014/15, and 2015/16 And Other Incidental Findings published by the Public Accounts Committee of the Parliament of Lesotho, '[Econet Telecom Lesotho] claims that it is not making profits but this is hard to believe as the Committee suspects transfer pricing practices. Again, the services have not improved as expected when the loan was secured for Econet. The Committee [is] concerned the Government of Lesotho is shouldering the burden of paying the loans on behalf of Econet while Econet is not remitting anything to the Government [of Lesotho].'
staff_comments: 1. This project is also known as the Econet Telecom Lesotho (ETL) National Network Phase II Project.  The Chinese project title is 莱索托全国通讯网络二期项目 or 莱索托国家电信网络项目二期. 2. Government concessional loans from China Eximbank are denominated in RMB, so AidData relies on the face value of the loan (RMB 200 million) reported by the IMF. In the the database of Chinese loan commitments that it released in July 2020, SAIS-CARI refers to the face value of the loan as $9 million, which is substantially lower than the values reported by the IMF (RMB 200 million), the World Bank ($36 million), the Government of Lesotho ($20 million), and the Public Accounts Committee (M245,297,692.05). 3. SAIS-CARI also identifies this project as reaching the loan signature (i.e. official commitment) stage but not the implementation stage or completion stage. However, AidData records this project as completed based on the May 31, 2013 handover date reported by the Chinese Government.4. According to the World Bank's Debtor Reporting System (DRS), the weighted average maturity of all official sector lending from Chinese creditors to government and government-guaranteed borrowing institutions in Lesotho was 19.7499 years in 2011. AidData estimates the maturity of the China Eximbank loan that supported Phase 2 of the National Telecom Network Project by using this figure. See https://www.dropbox.com/s/949n5rctiue6d7c/IDS_Average_grace_period_and_maturity_on_new_external_debt_commitments.xlsx?dl=0   5. According to the World Bank's Debtor Reporting System (DRS), the weighted average grace period of all official sector lending from Chinese creditors to government and government-guaranteed borrowing institutions in Lesotho was 5.2499 years in 2011. AidData estimates the grace period of the China Eximbank loan that supported Phase 2 of the National Telecom Network Project by using this figure. See https://www.dropbox.com/s/949n5rctiue6d7c/IDS_Average_grace_period_and_maturity_on_new_external_debt_commitments.xlsx?dl=0   6. According to the World Bank's Debtor Reporting System (DRS), the weighted average interest rate of all official sector lending from Chinese creditors to government and government-guaranteed borrowing institutions in Lesotho was 2% in 2011. AidData estimates the interest rate of the China Eximbank loan that supported Phase 2 of the National Telecom Network Project by using this figure. See https://www.dropbox.com/s/ab8qt4n6jijcbhd/IDS_Average%20interest%20on%20new%20external%20debt%20commitments.xlsx?dl=07. China Eximbank also provided a loan for Phase 1 of the National Telecom Network Project (captured via Project ID#752).
combined_text:
# Sector
COMMUNICATIONS

# Title
China Eximbank provides RMB 200 million government concessional loan for Phase 2 of National Telecom Network Project (Linked to Project ID#752)

# Description
On August 10, 2011, the Chinese Government and the Government of Lesotho signed a concessional loan framework agreement for Phase 2 of the National Telecom Network Project. Then, on December 12, 2011, China Eximbank and the Government of Lesotho signed a government concessional loan (GCL) agreement worth RMB 200 million to support Phase 2 of the National Telecom Network Project. The borrowing terms of the GCL are unknown.   The Government of Lesotho used the proceeds of the loan to on-lend to Econet Telecom Lesotho, a state-owned telecommunications operator in Lesotho. Econet Telecom Lesotho (ETL), in turn, used the loan proceeds to expand, upgrade and modernize Lesotho’s telecommunications infrastructure. Anhui Telecom Engineering Co. was the contractor responsible for Phase 2. Work appears to have began shortly after Anhui Telecom Engineering Co. signed an implementation agreement on April 24, 2012. The project was officially handed over to the Government of Lesotho on May 31, 2013.   ETL did not honor its repayment obligations to the Government of Lesotho under the terms of its on-lending agreement. According to a Report on the Consolidated Financial Statements of the Government of Lesotho for the Three Years 2013/14, 2014/15, and 2015/16 And Other Incidental Findings published by the Public Accounts Committee of the Parliament of Lesotho, '[Econet Telecom Lesotho] claims that it is not making profits but this is hard to believe as the Committee suspects transfer pricing practices. Again, the services have not improved as expected when the loan was secured for Econet. The Committee [is] concerned the Government of Lesotho is shouldering the burden of paying the loans on behalf of Econet while Econet is not remitting anything to the Government [of Lesotho].'
justification: Project focuses on telecommunications infrastructure without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Expansion and modernization of Lesotho's telecommunications infrastructure, no direct energy or environmental components mentioned

title: Chinese Embassy donates M150,000 LSL to the Office of the First Lady of Lesotho
description: On November 9, 2011, the Chinese Embassy in Lesotho donated M150,000 LSL to the Office of the First Lady of Lesotho in order to help orphans and vulnerable children in Lesotho. Mathato Mosisili was the First Lady of Lesotho by virtue of being the wife of Prime Minister of Lesotho Pakalitha Mosisili. The funds were set to be used to buy sanitary towels for school girls in need, as well for the acquisition of sewing machines and construction of shacks to allow young people to begin small businesses.
combined_text:
# Sector
OTHER SOCIAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND SERVICES

# Title
Chinese Embassy donates M150,000 LSL to the Office of the First Lady of Lesotho

# Description
On November 9, 2011, the Chinese Embassy in Lesotho donated M150,000 LSL to the Office of the First Lady of Lesotho in order to help orphans and vulnerable children in Lesotho. Mathato Mosisili was the First Lady of Lesotho by virtue of being the wife of Prime Minister of Lesotho Pakalitha Mosisili. The funds were set to be used to buy sanitary towels for school girls in need, as well for the acquisition of sewing machines and construction of shacks to allow young people to begin small businesses.
justification: Project is a social development initiative with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Donation for orphans and vulnerable children, focus on social welfare and small business support
